Literature Review:
Endogenous retroelements, including endogenous retroviruses (ERVs), are remnants of ancient viral infections that have integrated into the host genome. These elements constitute a significant portion of the mammalian genome, with approximately 8% of the human genome being composed of ERVs (Lander et al., 2001). The immunological conundrum posed by these elements arises from their dual nature: while they are part of the host genome, they retain the potential to be recognized as foreign by the immune system. This review explores the complex interplay between endogenous retroelements and the immune system, focusing on the innate and adaptive immune responses, the consequences of immune recognition, and the implications for health and disease.

The innate immune system serves as the first line of defense against pathogens, including retroelements. Pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) such as Toll-like receptors (TLRs) and cytosolic sensors like RIG-I and MDA5 play crucial roles in detecting viral components, including those derived from ERVs (Takeuchi & Akira, 2010). Upon recognition, these receptors trigger signaling pathways that lead to the production of type I interferons and other pro-inflammatory cytokines, which are essential for controlling viral infections (Kawai & Akira, 2006). However, the activation of these pathways by endogenous retroelements can also lead to chronic inflammation and contribute to autoimmune diseases when not properly regulated (Crow, 2010).

Adaptive immunity, characterized by the specificity and memory of immune responses, also plays a role in recognizing endogenous retroelements. T cells and B cells can mount responses against retroviral antigens, which are sometimes expressed by ERVs (Young et al., 2013). The presentation of these antigens by major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules can lead to the activation of autoreactive T cells, contributing to autoimmune pathologies (Pereira et al., 2009). Moreover, the expression of ERV proteins has been implicated in the pathogenesis of diseases such as multiple sclerosis and systemic lupus erythematosus, where they may act as autoantigens (Balada et al., 2009).

Despite the potential for pathogenicity, endogenous retroelements also play beneficial roles in the immune system. For instance, ERVs have been shown to contribute to the regulation of immune responses and the development of immune tolerance. The expression of ERV-derived peptides can promote the selection of regulatory T cells, which are crucial for maintaining immune homeostasis and preventing autoimmunity (Faria et al., 2013). Additionally, ERVs have been implicated in the enhancement of immune responses against tumors, a process known as cancer immunosurveillance. The expression of ERV antigens in tumor cells can make them more recognizable to the immune system, facilitating their elimination (Chiappinelli et al., 2015).

The interaction between endogenous retroelements and the immune system is further complicated by the influence of epigenetic regulation. ERVs are typically silenced by DNA methylation and histone modifications, preventing their transcription and subsequent immune recognition (Rebollo et al., 2012). However, disruptions in these epigenetic mechanisms can lead to the reactivation of ERVs, resulting in increased immunogenicity and the potential for inflammatory diseases (Manghera & Douville, 2013). Age-related changes in epigenetic regulation may also contribute to the increased expression of ERVs observed in older individuals, potentially linking them to age-related inflammation and diseases (De Cecco et al., 2013).

Recent studies have highlighted the role of endogenous retroelements in shaping the immune response to infections and the microbiota. ERVs can modulate the expression of genes involved in immune responses, influencing the host's ability to combat infections (Frank & Feschotte, 2017). Furthermore, the interaction between ERVs and the microbiota may have implications for immune system development and function, as the microbiota can influence the expression of ERVs and vice versa (Browne et al., 2015).

In conclusion, the immunological conundrum of endogenous retroelements lies in their ability to act as both self and non-self entities. While they pose challenges to immune regulation and can contribute to disease, they also play essential roles in immune system development and function. Understanding the complex interactions between endogenous retroelements and the immune system will provide insights into their contributions to health and disease, potentially leading to novel therapeutic strategies for autoimmune and inflammatory diseases, as well as cancer.
